   59M with h/o anemia, recent H.pylori gastritis transferred for severe

   # Respiratory failure: Patient arrived with severe respiratory acidosis
   with difficulty ventilating at OSH with evidence of aspiration there
   following and EGD. Admit CXR showing bilateral patchy infiltrates and
   breathing most likely [**2-23**] aspiration pneumonitis with severe

   improve ventilation, including decreasing PEEP, then decreasing rate to

   tachycardia on admission (now s/p chest tube placement overnight) .

   small to bronch through overnight and would be high risk to change tube
   given airway edema seen at OSH.  Patient appears more stable this

   heavily sedated but not paralyzed.  Patient likely had severe
   barotraumas in setting of very high pressures at OSH.
   .

   - monitor left chest tube drainage (about 80cc out serosanguinous

   still

The patient is diagnosed with acute respiratory failure, not ARDS, and sepsis without organ dysfunction. ICU care includes respiratory support, fluid management, glycemic control, line management, prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcers, and prevention of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential Medical Complications:
